abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            Tanzania River Basin Management and Smallholder Irrigation
            Improvement Project anticipates negative environmental
            impacts and proposes measures to mitigate them. Some of the
            measures recommended include: Arrest catchments degradation
            by promoting agro forestry agricultural practices,
            afforestation or reforestation, strengthening regulatory
            enforcement, promoting environmental consciousness, and
            strengthening measures for controlled acquisition and
            land-use practices. Avoid reduced water quantity, increased
            incidences of waterborne diseases, and poor water quality by
            setting mechanism for resolving water conflicts, promoting
            irrigation agriculture, preparing and implementing a
            participatory land use plan, promoting awareness of
            waterborne diseases as well as HIV/AIDS, and improving
            availability of health, water, and sanitation services.
            Minimize sand at intake structure by promoting upstream soil
            and water conservation and environmental protection.
            Maintain water availability for irrigation by establishing
            effective water management system. Avoid effects on soil and
            water quality by educating users on appropriate irrigation
            practices. Reduce fertilizer and pesticide use by employing
            integrated pest management system and soil fertility
            management. Improve drainage including disposal of water to
            evaporation ponds if water quality is adversely affected by
            drainage water. Monitor water salinity. After construction
            phase is completed, build bridge crossings for livestock,
            refill borrow pits, provide water troughs to downstream
            users, supply proper drainage to avoid backwater flooding,
            construct proper dykes to reduce flooding, and introduce
            adequate field service roads and crossings for easy access
            of harvests and services.
